thread.title: Malcolm Turnbull's MPs jostle for ministries
thread.title_full: Malcolm Turnbull's MPs jostle for ministries | afr.com

author: afr.com
title: Malcolm Turnbull's MPs jostle for ministries
text:
Treasurer Joe Hockey addresses the media during a joint press conference with Commissioner of Taxation Chris Jordan. Alex Ellinghausen by Phillip Coorey Primrose Riordan Immigration Minister Peter Dutton is tipped to resign from Cabinet while Joe Hockey has discussed with Malcolm Turnbull staying in the ministry but taking another portfolio.
A stoic Mr Hockey, who will be replaced as Treasurer by Social Services Minster in the cabinet reshuffle scheduled for Monday, went about his business on Wednesday by doing a press conference with the Tax Commissioner Chris Jordan to announce the government was moving ahead with a crackdown on multi-national tax evasion.
Mr Jordan praised the work Mr Hockey had done internationally on the issue.
But Mr Hockey would not say whether he would be Treasurer this time next week, saying that was up to Mr Turnbull.
Mr Hockey would not say whether he would be Treasurer this time next week, saying that was up to Mr Turnbull. "I have had discussions with the Prime Minster, we'll leave it at that," he said.
"I want to make a difference for Australia."
"I have a job to do. It's what I swore on the 'Bible' to the Governor-General I would do. I am continuing to do my job to the best of my ability."
He urged those still angry over Monday's leadership coup to try to unify behind Mr Turnbull, warning disunity would see Labor win government.
 Mr Turnbull also got down to business by signing the national Disability Insurance Scheme Agreements with the Premiers of NSW and Victoria. He is also busy fielding calls from foreign leaders and has spoken on Wednesday to United States President Barack Obama.
As Mr Turnbull looks to refresh his line up, current ministers who backed Mr Abbott were also active.
Cormann: 'Team player' Employment Minster Eric Abetz was flagging a Senate breakthrough in industrial relations legislation, Defence Minister Kevin Andrews was announcing the first bombs dropped in Syria by the Air Force, and Trade Minister Andrew Robb introduced to Parliament legislation for the China-Australia Free Trade Agreement.
While Commentator Andrew Bolt suggested disgruntled Liberal Senator Cory Bernardi may need to lead a new conservative party, Assistant Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, Finance Minister Mathias Cormann, who voted for Tony Abbott, pledged their support for Mr Turnbull.
"I support unequivocally our new leader, I am a team player, I always have been, always will be. Malcolm Turnbull will have by complete, absolute, unequivocal and loyal support and I will support his effort in whatever capacity he sees fit," Senator Cormann said.
"My responsibility is to get behind Malcolm," Mr Frydenberg said on Wednesday, saying he was throwing his support behind the new leader.
Andrews: 'Continuity' As he announced that Australian hornets has bombed an Islamic State personnel carrier two days ago, revealed by US CENTCOM, Mr Andrews suggested it would be disruptive if he was shifted out of his ministry.
"An Australian hornet fighter aircraft destroyed a Daesh armoured personnel carrier with a precision guided missile."
"I think continuity at the moment is quite important in this instance, we are operating in this mission in Iraq, we still have forces in Afghanistan, we are virtually weeks away from the publication fo the Defence white paper," he said.
Mr Andrews said while he did not usually announce when each bomb was dropped, he said the announcement was part of a six monthly update on operations in the Middle East.
Mr Frydenberg said he had written to his constituents yesterday to explain why he supported Tony Abbott in the ballot.
Brandis: 'Ancient history' Senator George Brandis has revealed publicly that "he was becoming increasingly concerned Tony Abbott's leadership was becoming irretrievable" and the Abbott government "struggled to make itself understood".
Senator Brandis said Mr Turnbull's failures in opposition were "ancient history", and said Menzies and Howard both struggled as opposition leaders.
ABC's Insiders host Barry Cassidy reported this morning that Mr Hockey may be offered the Communications portfolio, Michaelia Cash may rise to Immigration, and Arthur Sinodinos might get employment.
